title: Pepper — Bacterial spot
text:
Symptoms: small, water-soaked leaf spots that turn dark/brown with yellow halos; scabby raised lesions on fruit. Often worse after warm, wet, windy weather.
Scouting: inspect lower and mid canopy; look at both leaf surfaces and young fruit; check after rains/overhead irrigation.
Immediate actions: remove badly infected leaves/fruit from the field (dispose, don’t compost); avoid working plants when wet; switch to drip if possible.
IPM: rotate 2–3 seasons away from solanaceous crops; plant certified seed/seedlings; use resistant/tolerant varieties if available; sanitize tools; manage weeds; ensure good spacing and airflow.
Chemical (general): copper-based bactericides may help protect new growth when applied preventively; follow local labels and consult extension.
When to escalate: rapid spread under wet weather; fruit losses rising—seek local extension advice.

title: Pepper — Healthy crop care
text:
Routine care: use certified seedlings; harden off before transplanting; maintain 30–45 cm plant spacing and 75–100 cm between rows for airflow.
Water & nutrition: prefer drip; water early morning; soil test to guide N–P–K; avoid excess nitrogen that drives soft growth.
Sanitation: weed control; remove plant debris after harvest; disinfect tools.
Monitoring: scout weekly for spots, wilting, sucking pests; record issues.
Preventive IPM: mulch to reduce splash; rotate away from tomatoes/potatoes; stake where needed.

title: Potato — Early blight
text:
Symptoms: brown lesions with concentric target-like rings on older leaves; yellow halo; can cause defoliation and yield loss.
Scouting: start at lower canopy; check older leaves first; look after dry periods followed by humidity.
Immediate actions: remove heavily infected foliage; ensure balanced nutrition (adequate K); avoid overhead irrigation in late day.
IPM: rotate 2+ seasons; destroy volunteer potatoes; use certified seed; maintain spacing and hilling to keep tubers covered.
Chemical (general): protectant fungicides work best preventively and in a program; follow local guidance.
When to escalate: lesions appearing on many plants/rapid defoliation.

title: Potato — Healthy crop care
text:
Routine care: plant certified, disease-free seed in well-drained soils; rotate 2–3 years; hill to prevent greening.
Water & nutrition: regular, even moisture (avoid cycles of drought/flood); soil test; adequate K and Ca improve skin quality.
Sanitation: remove cull piles; control volunteers; clean equipment.
Monitoring: scout weekly for leaf spots, wilts, aphids, late blight weather alerts.

title: Potato — Late blight
text:
Symptoms: water-soaked lesions on leaves/stems that rapidly expand; white fuzzy growth on undersides in humid conditions; tuber rot possible.
Scouting: check field edges and low spots first; inspect after cool, wet weather; look early morning.
Immediate actions: remove/rogue hot spots (severely affected plants); avoid overhead irrigation; improve airflow.
IPM: plant certified seed; destroy volunteers; tight rotation; avoid excess leaf wetness; choose tolerant varieties when available.
Chemical (general): fungicides are preventive; follow local spray advisories and labels.
When to escalate: fast spread across rows, stem infections, or weather favors disease.

title: Tomato — Target spot (Corynespora)
text:
Symptoms: brown spots with concentric rings, often with yellow halos; can coalesce causing blight; fruit can show dark, sunken spots.
Scouting: inspect mid-to-lower canopy; after warm, humid nights; check both leaf surfaces.
Immediate actions: remove heavily infected leaves; improve airflow; avoid leaf wetness late in the day.
IPM: rotate 2–3 seasons; sanitize stakes/strings; balanced nutrition; resistant/tolerant cultivars if available.
Chemical (general): use protectant fungicides preventively during conducive weather; follow labels.
When to escalate: lesions rapidly increasing; fruit symptoms appearing.

title: Tomato — Tomato mosaic virus (ToMV)
text:
Symptoms: light/dark green mosaic/mottling, leaf narrowing/shoestring, stunting; fruit may be small or malformed.
Scouting: look for patterned chlorosis rather than necrotic spots; check new growth.
Immediate actions: rogue symptomatic plants to limit spread; wash hands, sanitize tools; avoid tobacco handling.
IPM: use resistant cultivars; control seed/seedling sources; sanitize trays and tools; avoid mechanical transmission; manage greenhouse hygiene.
When to escalate: many plants showing mosaic across blocks.

title: Tomato — TYLCV (yellow leaf curl)
text:
Symptoms: upward curling, yellowing of young leaves, stunting, reduced fruit set; transmitted by whiteflies.
Scouting: focus on new growth; monitor whitefly populations (undersides of leaves).
Immediate actions: remove highly symptomatic plants; manage whiteflies (cultural controls, physical barriers, approved controls as per local guidance).
IPM: use tolerant varieties and insect-exclusion nets where feasible; weed control; reflective mulches can deter vectors; avoid overlapping crops that harbor whiteflies.
When to escalate: rapid spread and high vector counts.

title: Tomato — Bacterial spot
text:
Symptoms: small, dark leaf spots with yellow halos; fruit with raised, scabby lesions; defoliation in severe cases.
Scouting: check lower canopy and after storms; inspect fruit set stages.
Immediate actions: remove infected foliage/fruit; avoid working plants when wet; switch to drip irrigation.
IPM: resistant/tolerant cultivars; certified seed; sanitation; rotation 2–3 years; good airflow.
Chemical (general): copper-based products may help protect new growth; consult local guidance.
When to escalate: fast spread during wet periods or fruit lesions increasing.

title: Tomato — Early blight
text:
Symptoms: brown spots with concentric rings (target-like) on older leaves; yellow halo; stem/fruit can be affected.
Scouting: inspect lower leaves first; look after humidity or rainfall.
Immediate actions: remove blighted leaves; stake/prune to improve airflow; irrigate at soil level.
IPM: rotate 2+ seasons; sanitize debris; balanced fertilization (avoid excess N, ensure K); resistant varieties when available.
Chemical (general): protectants work best preventively; follow labels.
When to escalate: lesions expanding up the canopy or fruit infection starts.

title: Tomato — Healthy crop care
text:
Routine care: use certified seedlings and resistant cultivars; stake/trellis and prune to open canopy.
Water & nutrition: drip irrigation preferred; water early day; soil test to guide fertilization; mulch to reduce splash.
Sanitation: remove lower leaves touching soil; clean tools; weed control.
Monitoring: weekly scouting for spots, yellowing, wilts, mites/whiteflies; record and act early.

title: Tomato — Late blight
text:
Symptoms: water-soaked, rapidly expanding lesions on leaves/stems; white downy growth on undersides under humidity; fruit brown/firm lesions.
Scouting: monitor during cool, wet periods; check field edges and lower canopy early morning.
Immediate actions: remove hot spots; avoid leaf wetness; increase airflow; destroy volunteer hosts.
IPM: resistant/tolerant cultivars where available; rotation; sanitation; avoid overhead irrigation in evenings.
Chemical (general): fungicides are preventive/systemic depending on label; follow local advisories.
When to escalate: spread across rows within days or stem infections observed.

title: Tomato — Leaf mold (Passalora/Cladosporium)
text:
Symptoms: pale/yellow spots on upper leaf and olive-green/gray velvety growth on underside; thrives in high humidity and poor airflow; usually not on fruit.
Scouting: inspect undersides of leaves in dense canopy/greenhouse.
Immediate actions: improve ventilation; reduce humidity; remove infected leaves; water at soil level.
IPM: wider spacing, pruning, sanitation; disinfect greenhouse surfaces; resistant cultivars if available.
Chemical (general): protectant fungicides can help when used early.
When to escalate: persistent humidity and increasing leaf loss.

title: Tomato — Septoria leaf spot
text:
Symptoms: many small circular spots with dark margins and tan centers; tiny black dots (pycnidia) in centers; starts on lower leaves and moves up.
Scouting: check lower canopy weekly; after rains or overhead irrigation.
Immediate actions: remove infected lower leaves; mulch soil; avoid splashing.
IPM: rotate 2+ years; sanitize debris; stake/prune for airflow; drip irrigation.
Chemical (general): protectants used preventively can slow spread; follow labels.
When to escalate: rapid upward movement and canopy thinning.

title: Tomato — Two-spotted spider mite
text:
Symptoms: fine stippling/yellow speckling on leaves, bronzing, webbing on undersides; hot/dry weather favors outbreaks.
Scouting: use hand lens on undersides; check field edges and dusty areas.
Immediate actions: hose off leaves with water if feasible; remove heavily infested leaves; reduce plant stress.
IPM: maintain humidity in greenhouse; avoid dusty conditions; conserve natural enemies; consider reflective mulch.
Chemical (general): use miticides only when thresholds are met and rotate modes of action per local guidance.
When to escalate: webbing visible and leaves bronzing across plants.
